required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Testing Miglustat Administration in Subjects With Spastic Paraplegia 11
clinical_study.official_title: Phase 2 Pharmacological Trial to Evaluate the Safety of Miglustat Administration in Subjects With Spastic Paraplegia 11 (TreatSPG11)

brief_summary.textblock:
Hereditary spastic paraparesis type 11 (SPG11) is caused by mutations in the SPG11 gene that produces spatacsin, a protein involved in lysosomal function. Studies performed in skin cells (fibroblasts) from SPG11 patients, mice and zebrafish models of the disease showed that the material accumulated in the lysosomes is made of glycosphingolipids (GSL).
Miglustat is a drug that inhibits an enzyme called glucosylceramide synthetase (GCS) which is used for the production of GSL. Miglustat, therefore, helps to delay the production of GSL. This study aims to collect preliminary data on the safety of miglustat on the SPG11 disease and to assess biomarkers.

primary_outcome.measure: 1-Changes from baseline blood tests at 24 weeks 2-Changes from baseline neurophysiological tests at 24 weeks 3-Report of severe adverse events

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes from baseline GM2/GM3 levels at 24 weeks
Assess changes in the scores of the Spastic Paraplegia Rating Scale (SPRS) at 24 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: SPRS rates disease severity (0-52) with lower numbers indicating less impairement

arm_group.arm_group_label: Evaluate the safety of Miglustat administration in subjects with Spastic Paraplegia 11
arm_group.description: 100 mg of Miglustat, 3 caps per day for first 4 weeks; 100 mg of Miglustat, 6 caps per day for 8 weeks

intervention.description: Evaluate safety and tolerability of Miglustat in a group of subjects affected of SPG11.
intervention.arm_group_label: Evaluate the safety of Miglustat administration in subjects with Spastic Paraplegia 11
